Production is the provision of goods and services in order to satisfy human needs and wants[cite: 3].
The three branches of production are industry, commerce, and direct services[cite: 4, 42].

Industry deals with the extraction of natural resources (raw materials) and transforming them into semi-finished or finished goods[cite: 5]. It is divided into extractive (primary), manufacturing (secondary), and construction (secondary)[cite: 47, 48, 49].

Commerce deals with the distribution of both raw materials and finished goods from the source/place of extraction or manufacturing to the place of demand/scarcity[cite: 6]. It includes trade and aids to trade (warehousing, communication, transport, insurance, banking, and advertising) which help distribute goods and services to consumers[cite: 51, 52].

Direct services are non-material goods [cite: 54] that play an indirect role in production by enhancing it[cite: 7]. Examples include services rendered by teachers, doctors, architects, the police, and lawyers[cite: 8].
There are two main types of production methods: Direct Production and Indirect Production[cite: 10].
Direct Production is the production of goods for one's own use on a subsistence level, satisfying only one's own needs and wants without needing exchange with others[cite: 12, 13].
Indirect Production is the production for the benefit of others, which involves trading what has been produced. It depends upon trade and encourages people to specialize in one field[cite: 15, 16].

Factors of production are essential resources or inputs that must be in place before any production can take place[cite: 18]. They are Land, Labour, Capital, and Enterprise/Entrepreneurship[cite: 19].

Land implies the place or venue where production is done[cite: 20]. It includes all natural resources like copper, coal, fish, water, animals, and trees[cite: 21, 22]. The reward for land is Rent or Rates[cite: 23].
Labour is the human effort applied in production[cite: 25]. It may be Manual/physical (unskilled) or professional/mental (skilled)[cite: 26]. The reward for labour is a salary or a wage[cite: 28].
Capital refers to resources that man uses to produce goods and services[cite: 30]. Examples are money, buildings, machinery, and raw materials[cite: 31]. The reward for capital is interest[cite: 33].

Enterprise/Entrepreneurship is the ability to organize other factors of production and involves making decisions like business expansion and investing[cite: 35, 37]. The reward for entrepreneurs is profit or loss[cite: 39].

Specialisation is the process where individuals, businesses, or countries focus on producing specific goods or services efficiently[cite: 68]. This leads to higher productivity, better quality, and cost reduction[cite: 69]. A disadvantage is that it may create dependency on other producers for goods and services[cite: 72].

Original goods are durable, expensive, and attractive[cite: 63]. Quality goods meet customer expectations in terms of performance, durability, and aesthetics[cite: 64]. Substandard goods fail to meet customer expectations in terms of quality and reliability[cite: 66]. Counterfeit goods are fake or unauthorised replicas of real products[cite: 67].
